intro: Symplocos quitensis, commonly known as the Andean wax tree, is a deciduous shrub or small tree native to the Andean regions of South America. It belongs to the Ericaceae family and is characterized by its elliptical, glossy leaves and showy, bell-shaped flowers that range in color from white to pink. The plant produces small, dark berries that are an important food source for various wildlife species. Symplocos quitensis is adapted to high-altitude environments and thrives in well-drained, acidic soils. Its ornamental value and ecological significance make it a notable species in its native habitat.
